title: COVID-19 vaccine For Kids: Is it safe for your kids to be around people who have received the shot?
description: The complexity is that there is no vaccine available for kids below 18 years, so it is more challenging to protect them from getting infected.
cleaned_text: kid meet vaccinated people? More kids have fallen victim to the second wave of coronavirus as compared to the first one. Kids who were mostly considered as the silent carrier of the virus till now have started developing severe symptoms that last long after their recovery. The complexity is that there is no vaccine available for kids below 18 years, so it is more challenging to protect them from getting infected. This makes it more important to encourage kids to stay at home to cut down the risk of infection. But there is a growing concern among parents if they should let their kids meet relatives and other family members who have been vaccinated. Are they safe around them or do they need to follow any protocols? [readmore](javascript://) 02/4Should you let your kids meet other people who are vaccinated? Getting the coronavirus shot means the person builds immunity against the virus, but it does not mean they cannot be infected with the virus or it is not present around them. Even after getting the jab, a person may carry the virus without showing any symptoms. Besides, no vaccine guarantees complete protection against the virus. The efficacy of the vaccine currently being administered maybe 80% to 90% but its effectiveness varies in the real world due to several factors. Secondly, the virus can be present anywhere like on different surfaces and can be easily passed on to kids while playing or engaging in some other activity. So, it is better for the time being to maintain social distance, practice regular hand hygiene, wear a mask and stay away from people who do not live together in the same household. [readmore](javascript://) 03/4How long do your kids need to maintain distance? It is important to maintain social distance from others, even when they are vaccinated till the time we do not gain complete information about the durability of immunity developed after getting the vaccine and asymptomatic infection in people who have been vaccinated. The vaccines being administered to people does not guarantee life long protection from the virus. This issue is still being explored and till the time proper information is not available, it is crucial to follow all the COVID-19 norms. The vaccine only protects those who have got the shot, not the people present around them. [readmore](javascript://) 04/4A vaccinated person may be the carrier of the virus Coronavirus is airborne and can survive on different surfaces for several days. If a vaccinated person comes in contact with the virus while talking to an infected person or by touching the contaminated surface, they can still carry the virus in their nose. As they have been vaccinated they may not develop any symptoms but they can pass on to others.
